author: mratsim
content: When you do Tonelli-Shanks, there is a large part that has to be computed and can be accelerated via addition chains and a part that depends on input and prime modulus. If prime modulus is congruent to 3 mod 4, there is actually no input dependent part and you can do full addition chain. if prime modulus is congruent to 5 mod 8, there is only 1 computation that may be skipped if not constant-time. 2 if p congruent to 1 mod 16, etc

author: mratsim
content: I have a full example here on BLS12-377: https://github.com/mratsim/constantine/blob/master/sage/square_root_bls12_377.sage#L133-L145

author: mratsim
content: Addition chains are really about minimizing the number of additions/squarings, see: https://www.briansmith.org/ecc-inversion-addition-chains-01
